document_title: Arm lymphedema: Causes, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Arm lymphedema is a phenomenon of fluid accumulation and stagnation in the lymphatic system, leading to arm swelling. The patient feels pain and has difficulty moving and moving the limbs, causing difficulty in daily activities. Arm lymphedema is a sequela after breast cancer treatment (accounting for about 10-15%). In particular, this condition can appear in patients who have had axillary lymph node dissection, and the risk is increased in patients who have had axillary radiotherapy.
Lymphedema can appear days, weeks, months or even years after cancer treatment. Arm lymphedema cannot be completely cured, but it helps reduce symptoms and prevent other symptoms, importantly preventing damage to the hands.
subsection_title: phu bach huyet canh tay.json. What is arm lymphedema?
